Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Adaptation to Abrupt Climate Change (A2C2)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award facilitates the interdisciplinary training of Ph.D. natural and social scientists in adaptation to abrupt climate change, one of the greatest challenges to the sustainability of human society and ecosystem services in the 21st century.

Intellectual Merit: This program meets the challenge of abrupt climate change by training students to conduct collaborative, interdisciplinary research across the natural and social sciences, and to develop innovative policy and management solutions from their research that fosters resilience and adaptation in response to abrupt climate change. Research themes focus on three major challenges that society faces with abrupt climate change: threats to global security, reductions in ecosystem services, and adaptation in social systems. Novel training elements of this program include a collaborative interdisciplinary research project, and a policy and management internship with organizations that span international, federal and state agencies, as well as the private sector.

Broader Impacts: The risks of abrupt climate change are globally pervasive and include increased numbers of environmental refugees and political conflicts over resources. Determining how to anticipate, avoid, and manage abrupt climate change was recently identified as one of the five grand challenges to global sustainability. This IGERT award trains the next generation of scientists to meet these environmental and social challenges. To promote future recruitment of a diverse science workforce, all IGERT trainees will conduct outreach activities with K-12 students from underrepresented groups. The program also fosters a strong international perspective through research collaborations as well as internship experiences abroad.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to establish new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries, and to engage students in understanding the processes by which research is translated to innovations for societal benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Adaptation to Abrupt Climate Change (A2C2) IGERT program at the University of Maine was designed to foster enhanced understanding of the dynamics of coupled natural and human systems in response to abrupt/rapid climate change, with program research being organized around the following core questions:

 a)  How does abrupt climate change (ACC) alter the dynamics of coupled natural and human (CNH) systems?

 b)  How do we inform policy and management to improve environmental security by enhancing resilience and adaptation of CNH systems experiencing ACC?

Over the course of our program, our trainees and faculty collaborated on numerous research projects focused on a variety of different types of ACC in many locations around the world. Our research addressed rapid climate change currently occurring in the Arctic, in alpine and coastal regions of Peru, Chile, and Argentina, and right in our own backyard in the lakes and coastal marine ecosystems of Maine.

By integrating social/ethnographic study with novel biophysical monitoring/experimentation, modeling, and analysis, our research groups advanced the frontiers of knowledge by creating an integrated interdisciplinary framework that has already helped to identify and fill knowledge gaps in a variety of coupled natural-human systems facing the threat of abrupt climate change. Through active and ongoing dissemination of the results of this interdisciplinary research by way of peer-reviewed academic publications, educational brochures, web sites, and numerous presentations at various meetings and public forums, our trainees and participating faculty strengthened their commitment to innovative scientific management of natural resources, thereby providing the general public with a clear example of the benefits of publicly-funded scientific research and increasing their understanding of and appreciation for the scientific enterprise in general.

Our students also had numerous opportunities to conduct research and internships abroad to enhance their global perspective and expand the geographic scope of their research and its application to populations that are vulnerable to abrupt climate change. Students investigated research questions addressing connections between contemporary ACC and ecological processes in the Arctic, continental ice sheet melting and iceberg dynamics, and implications of various non-Western ideologies for adaptation strategies - among others - which were best addressed through international work. In conducting this work, our students became keenly aware that the impacts of abrupt climate change cross borders and came to understand that professionals working in the realm of adaptation must become familiar with differences across cultures to achieve success. The international opportunities in this IGERT broadened our students' perspectives and provided them with tremendous opportunities that they almost certainly would not have enjoyed in more traditional graduate training programs.
